roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We'll hear argument next in Number oh one four fifty five, the Franconia Associates versus United States, and the Grass Valley Terrace versus United States.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Justice, and may it please the Court.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Eckland, you you began by saying you're seeking fair compensation for something.
We are Justice Scalia, we are seeking compensation for the breach of contra-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: you think you have a separate cause of action for the Government's violation of the Constitution, assuming y- that that that you're correct that that's what it's done?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Oh, quite so, Your Honor, yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It is with the Department of Agriculture, Your Honor, through the...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, it c- it comes no.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: with your argument is that if you have your whole property claim here rests upon the contract.
Well, petitioners pled, Justice Souter, the takings claim in the alternative to the breach of contract claim.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If they are correct, then I don't see how you've got a taking because your your whole property interest the only property interest you're asserting is an interest under that contract.
What's being taken, Justice Souter, is the expected use of the petitioners' properties.
to a certain period of time.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: contract for it, you have no right to expect it.
But there were representations by the Government that created a reasonable investment backed expectation on...
on the part of the pet-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: did the lower courts find that there was no contract claim? Because of the statute.
Because of the w- one judge, in particular, because of the unmistakability doctrine.
the contract was not clear enough to constitute an enforceable contract with the Government.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I thought the Federal Circuit went on the statute of limitations.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: on the basis of the statute...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: you presented is whether a breach of contract claim accrues for purposes of section twenty-fi- when Congress enacts a statute alleged to abridge a contractual right to freedom from regulatory cavants [: covenants] upon prepayment of Govern- mortgage loans.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And that's the case we have here.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Didn't the Federal Circuit rely on anticipatory breach?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: on anticipatory breach, as I understand it.

We do not either, Your Honor, although the petitioners here have the option of suing assuming suing before the breach, assuming that they had the ability to perform at that time and there's nothing in the record...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the notion that before they went to pay it off, it was an anticipatory breach.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: that the reason the statute of limitations doesn't arise, doesn't start to run prior to the time that they paid it off, is because prior to that time, there was no actual breach.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: but you take the position that your clients could have filed suit f- soon after the passage of ELIHPA.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: take the position let's be clear about...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: please that after the enactment of the statute, your c- clients could have filed suit for breach of contract on an anticipatory breach theory?
Yes, but only if they had the ability to prepay at that time.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: when when the obligation to perform comes.
You do have to show that you're but for the repudiation, you do have to show that you are able to perform.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: about here in performance means w- w- the ability to prepay.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I I have a contract to deliver a hundred thousand widgets three years from now.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: anticipatory breach most people use it not to get damages but to relieve themselves of the obligation of of remaining i- i- in in the status of being able to perform the contract.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It's never the case that he's ready to or almost never the case that he's ready here and now to perform.
But, Your Honor, if the person who had the obligation to accept the the delivery did not have the funds, for example, even to purchase them, then that would be sort of...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the funds until three years from now.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: this? Could we agree to this, that so far as the element of an anticipatory breach claim involves the act of the Government, you had that element, and at least to that extent, you could have brought an anticipatory breach claim when the statute was passed? Maybe you didn't have other elements.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: and But you're saying, whether I could've sued then or not, I certainly can sue at the point at which I would claim my right to redeem without these various conditions, and they refused to honor it.
And and the doctrine does not require you to sue until that date.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: for total control then over timing because your client could say, well, we're not ready after five years, we're not ready after seven years, we're not ready after ten years.
Because the Government negotiated option terms up to fifty...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: deal, and the owners relied on that when they signed up, and they had, you know, a clear expectation that at some point in time they would be able to prepay, opt out, and convert their...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Did they have a a right to assume right after the day after the statute was passed, did they continue to have a right to prepay,

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: N- Well, the right still existed, Your Honor, but it wasn't it was repudiated at the time of the statute.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, it wasn't just repudi- it's not like a private citizen saying, I don't intend to perform three years from now.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: maintain there was no breach at the time the law was passed?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: that the statute changed the -- your rights.

The statute did condition them, and that conditioning, or fettering as the Government says, is a repudiation, but like any other situation in the private sector, when you repudiate a right, the breach doesn't occur until the time for performance comes due.
Well, the breach is repudiation if...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: to change its mind? Couldn't the Government pass another statute going back to what ze [: the]

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, Justice Scalia, they could and they did.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: seventy-nine they initially conditioned the right, and in nineteen eighty they repealed it, retracted it.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: argu- about is whether a statute itself, without any ac- action from the agency, can be a repudiation.
We believe it can be a repudiation, yes, Mr. Chief Justice.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: D- Does the repudiation give you the right to the same damages that you would receive for a total breach of the contract?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I think it's usually the case, is it not, that when there's an anticipatory repudiation, it's v- it's very difficult for the the other party to determine what his damages are going to be.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: is why he uses the doctrine to get out of the contract rather than to seek damages.
Petitioners here, being in the Court of Federal Claims, have as their only remedy the monetary judgment.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So you are you s- you're saying that there was a claim, or you're saying that that your claim really doesn't accrue until you until you have the pre- the wherewithal to prepay.
We're saying th- the petitioners would at least have to have the money to prepay.
intent to perform and have the...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I have a problem with that,

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: c- if we can get b- b- for the same reason Justice Scalia mentioned.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: cash in the bank that would allow you to prepay, and then there's a...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: At that point, can't you show your damages? You don't want to prepay, but can't you say have an expert in and say, this property has a certain value and part of the value is the right t- i- i- at any time to b- prepay the the the loan and and use it for another use? And this can be valued in the real estate market.
But here, Justice Kennedy, a fifty year option exists.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: fifty year options are not subject to valuation? The experts do this all the time.

Well, but even so, even if you could come up with a damage theory to cover this, still it's clear that under the law, the breach would not be deemed to accrue for limitations purposes until the time for performance has arrived and performance failed.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You're you're just getting me confused again.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: what in the world you are arguing.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: if they had the ability to pay, you say.
According to Corbin and the case law that we cite at footnote twenty-three of our brief, yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: twenty-three just says that ordinary contract law applies to these this kind of case.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We still do- but we so we still have to figure out what ordinary contract law, footnote twenty-three doesn't shed any light on that that I saw.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: page twenty-seven of the blue brief you say that the law constituted an anticipatory repudiation and petitioners had the option of suing immediately.
In general, yes, that's true, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But the all petitioners commence suit within six years of the date of the actual breach, which is the date that the prepayment requests were denied.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So, what apparently the Government's arguing does it matter if we call this anticipatory repudiation or anticipatory breach? I guess technically...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: we should say anticipatory rebudiation? [: repudiation]

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And so what they say, in part, which I'd like hear your response, is that you're right that where there is anticipatory repudiation of a contract, the other side, if it's a private contract, has a choice.

Well, here Your Honor, although, yes, we need to construe the statute strictly, we cannot do so in such a manner, however, to narrow the waiver of sovereign immunity that has already occurred under the Tucker Act.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: then i- if that's the ca- I me- I mean I really do think that your takings claim, w- w- which is the reason you're going into this thing well, it was just a conditioning of the right it wasn't an elimination of the right it just reduced it you you do all of that to to support your takings claim.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: how you can say it was enough for an anticipatory breach, but it wasn't enough for a taking.
It it you are correct, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And that that's why you were confusing Justice O'Connor,

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: not really ready to say there was an anticipatory breach, because in order s- to sustain your takings claim, you don't really want to say there was an anticipatory breach because they didn't really, absolutely break the contract.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: both shoulders it seems to me, and and and you're spilling a lot.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: in every breach there's also a taking?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Why aren't weren't you satisfied with a breach of contract claim?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: what are you adding with this so called takings claim?

Well, in the event that the lower courts do not rule in the petitioners' favor on the contract claim, they have their wholly independent takings claim, which is based not it's not predicated on the existence of a contract.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Suppose you win on the first claim.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Suppose you win on the contract claim.
Well, there are differences between the claims, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: full benefit of your contract, which is what would happen if you win on your contract's claim.
If well in practical terms, Justice Scalia, if we do prevail on the contract claim at trial, I don't see that we would pursue the takings.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: you're asking us to do then is to write a little essay on a matter that affects millions of other people in a very serious way, in a case which doesn't seem completely to present the issue.
On behalf of petitioners I mean, we would not...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: to dismiss it too, I suppose.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: May I ask, because I I have to confess, I get getting a little confused, too.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: All we got before us the takings claim.
Prior to the time that the owners entered into this program, they owned their land.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Then they voluntarily agreed to these restrictions on the use, only a certain level of rent, only a certain income of tenants.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, well would you tell me what you think was taken? Is it the right to prepay that was taken?
If there is no contract right, then no, that was not taken, Your Honor.
their w- is is the is the permitted use of the property under their reasonable invex- investment backed expectation.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It's a regulatory taking of the right to make use of the property the way you wanted.
Which occurred prior to the time that they voluntarily agreed to participate in the program.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You mean before even before they signed the contract?
at or about the same time.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: assume you never made a contract claim.

It's just their inability to go back to using their proper- they the w- the way they were because of the passage of ELIHPA and the regulations that compelled them to continue charging only a certain level of rent.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: back a little? Did your clients borrow some money from the Federal Government at low interest rates?
The construction loan, Your Honor, in many cases was in- was initially from a private mortgage lender.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the borrower, your clients, had to exers- execute a loan agreement a and a- a promissory note...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And was the right of prepayment spelled out in any of those agreements?
The prepayment right itself was in the promissory note, yes,

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Chief Justice I see that most of my time is spent.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Roberts we'll hear from you.
[NS] Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: do you concede or should we take this case on the assumption that there was a contract? Do do we...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: assume it for purposes of deciding this case?
For the purposes of deciding the statute of limitations question, yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the contract included a right of...

Included a right of prepayment and not only a right of prepayment, because if the contract just said you can prepay at any time, it like all contracts would be presumed to be subject to subsequent legislation.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the my contract to pay a million dollars when my ship when the ships with grain come in, I say, a year in advance, ha ha, I'll never pay.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: cannot cannot break a contract then.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, the Government can always act by legislation, can't it?
and the Government can breach the...
contract and and be responsible for damages.

text_blocks.text: as it does it by legislation, it's okay.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: thought that was your point, that that this m- this breach is different because it was done by legislation.
That doesn't mean that that doesn't mean that it's not a breach, but what it means is that the breach is occurring at the time the legislation is...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: just curious to get into that a little bit is, I don't understand why the Government is taking the position it does, as well as what the position is.

What what we're what we're asking for is that people who believe that their contractual rights have been injured have been infringed by a statute give the Government reasonably prompt notice, in accordance with the statute of limitations, of their claims.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The the the damages are that petitioners had a loan that they allege gave them a an unfettered option to prepay at any time.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: to measure? Y- You you bet your life on that? I mean, the the reason the reason contract law has developed the option of suing for anticipatory breach as just an option is precisely because it is often so difficult to anticipate what your damages will be.
The damages, first of all, can be measured, as I said.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: mean, you know, my life expectancy can be measured, but I wouldn't bet a whole lot of money on it.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: you can come up with a guess for for for anything.
With With due respect, Your Honor, I d- I don't think that's the reason why the law gives the the option to the innocent party.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: if it is an option, why should the par- innocent party be penalized by having the sta- statute of limitations start to run then?
It's t- not an option here because the statute is a present breach.
to understand the nature of the promise that's that's that's at issue here, I think, and if if I could try to go back to...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: going to ask I I thek [: think] I s- I think it's consistent with w- the Chief Justice inquiry.

Our position is that there is an actual breach at the time that the statute is passed, and it's a breach of of the promise that the Government made that it wouldn't impose additional legal restrictions on prepayment.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Even though performance is not yet due.
It Performance on that promise is due, Your Honor.

text_blocks.text: to any contract that is ever made.
No, Your Honor, because s- because the the the difference is between legislation and the and the role that legislation has under background principles of contract law and other...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: principle of contract law is that we try to treat the Government and a private contracting party together.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: saying the fact that the Government can speak through legislation, whereas a private party cannot, alters that rule.
The The distinction Your Honor is that is is is two fold that legislation changes the legal rights and so there isn't an...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It may convert one right into a a a right to damages as opposed to a right to performance but the theory of contract is that by repudiation you can't just change the legal rights.
It does it does exactly that.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: then exactly the same thing is true in a private contract when there has been an anticipatory...

No, no, Your Honor, there might be a right to f- specific performance if it was the kind of contract that you could get specific performance, but we would submit that you couldn't get specific performance once the Government...
How does the fact that you cannot...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: what it does is show that there's i- there there's a change and an an injury right at the time that the legislation is...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It it's not going to apply in a private context because there isn't going to be a breach by virtue of of legislation unless there's a promise...
that the laws aren't going to...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: and, bingo, there is a breach of contract and you must sue at once.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You have no need to invent that.
Y- Y- You have no need to to have that additional promise in the private contract because because there isn't the presumption.
Well, what is what is your authority...

text_blocks.text: for the proposition that the y- and an anticipatory breach not accepted by the other party starts the statute of limitations rim- running? I mean, what case?
W- it's My My My My argument is not that this is an anticipatory breach.
that has to be there in a contract with the Government...

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: that it's a present breach? Do you still say that an anticipatory breach starts the statute running?
That that's not our principal submission.
you could read the statue you...
could read the statute that w- providing first accrues to mean that the first that when a plaintiff can first bring suit, that that's when the statute of limitations starts to...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: that's not the law as between private parties.
Yes, given the principles of sovereign immunity and the principle that the statute should be narr- narrowly...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: narrow construction notion, or construed strictly notion, applies to deciding whether there's a waiver by the Government of any...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The Court the Court has held several times that statutes of limitations, as conditions on the Government's waiver of its sovereign immunity, should themselves be be narrowly construed and has applied it in in in cases, for instance, involving a situation where a private party claimed that the limitations period didn't run until an administration administrative determination had been made that there wouldn't be that there was a lo- w- was a loss...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: in this sense, the Government actually needs less protection than the private party because the Government at least is in a position where it can always pass a statute of limitations...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: and if you're if you're if you're concerned about your liability fifty years out or something, I suppose you could pass a statute of limitations.
The Government ha- can do that and has done it here, and the statute of limitations provides that when the action first accrues, there's six years to sue.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, but ag- again, I'm I'm back to the problem.

In the in the ordinary situation, if a private party let's let's i- if if I may, let's c- can I pose a hypothetical? of a b- If if a if a private party had promised that you could prepay, that the other party could prepay at any time, and Congress passed a statute that imposed restrictions on prepayment, that statute would be neither an anticipatory repudiation or a breach, but would provide a discharge.
a- about on the merits of the plantiff's...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: you're saying that the in Government contracts, there is a promise and there is an issue whether the Government means that promise irrespective of what Congress does in the...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: what the Government meant was irrespective of what Congress does, and you're saying no, it meant only if Congress doesn't do to the contrary.
merits, on the merits, yes. But But...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: that kind of a contract issue is breached when Congress passes the law to the con-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: if it's just a background principle, I would worry about the practical consequence being of people, particularly in real estate contracts, having to study every regulation, every statute in order to tell their clients what to do.
And it's also important that Congress be able to cause a closi-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It could v- enact the the Congress that's close to the first one could say, okay, we'll repeal it.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Roberts, in the case in which the Government, we'll assume, doesn't change its mind, your argument in in response to Justice Breyer's question seems to boil down to something like this.
Well, W- When when there's a present when there's a breach, the the general principle is the statute of limitations starts to run at the time of the breach.
It doesn't wait to run until...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: your argument, as I understand it, is that because of the Government's peculiar power to pass legislation, the Government should not be in the position of the usual contract breaker who may be subject to an anticipatory breach claim or an actual breach claim later.
se- sus- there's a a very strong interest in permitting the Government to in permitting Congress to decide it wants to wrap up the costs of improvident Federal...
contracts that they have and and t-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: why don't we let Congress survey through the departments of the Government how many contracts it has entered into or guaranteed and taught up the damages in advance? The Government has access to this information if it wants to get it.
wi- The th- the Government doesn't know who's going to sue, for one.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the Government may get off a little cheaper if it puts the burden on the...
i- there's a dispute here as to whether the contract made this promise or not, and the Government doesn't doesn't know how that dispute's going to be resolved.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: contract law is not appried [: applied] you know, you know, you could say it from the point of view of general contract law, it's important that people who breach contracts know as soon as possible how much damage they've done, but obviously that doctrine has not commended itself in the area of general contract law.

Well, when they breach a contract and it's a breach, the the statute of limits does start to run and the rule is that even if the damages can't be fully ascertained, that that the statute of limitations run.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: it's so hard to look at this as an actual breach if we take it on the assumption there was a contractual right of prepayment on demand by the borrower.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Even under the scenario you posed that that there wasn't an incentive to prepay right at the moment, there's still a a change in what i- in in in the loan that petitioners have, and it's a loan where they no longer have that option to prepay...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the legislation, there still is consideration of the possibility of prepayment, but there're some new conditions imposed whereby the Government tries to assure itself that there will still be a certain number of low-income housing units out there on the market.
ye- ye- ye- Yes, Your Honor, but petitioners here aren't complaining about the fact that they're ultimately not able to prepay.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: there was a request to prepay.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: all petitioners have made requests to prepay.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: some of the petitioners in this case.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: to prepay and it's been refused.

At that point, there's an exacerbation in our view of the of the previous breach because it's an application of the restrictions that were imposed and that were imposed, according to petitioners' allegations, in violation of the Government's promise not to impose them.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: declaratory relief to determine your liabilities? Pick out...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I suppose that the Government could could do that.
for sure, but I don't know any...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: and you may not know the answer.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: you would y- y- i- it's I Do I have something that's that...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: case that you were bringing up.
I don't think that the c- that the case I I don't have a case one way or the other...
I think you'll find it's an anticipatory breach.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If you didn't make any pro- any other promise at all, it would be an anticipatory breach.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But you wouldn't have need to make that other promise because the because it would be presumed that you wouldn't take action that would d- d- you wouldn't be excused by taking action that makes it impossible for you to perform.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And your whole case hines [: hinges] on that, that the...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: rule for it would that make you...
All I can say to to that, Your Honor, is that that there are many situations in which damages cannot be ascertained fully.
and in not having to wait for fifty years to know...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: should want to have some rules out there that would encourage it to be able to deal with people on a commercial basis in some areas.
I I don't think it discourages them, Your Honor, because they they can sue and their damages are measurable, and they can get the damages.
